turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: I'm feeling really lost about my career. I have a degree in English Literature, but I don't want to teach. I've been working retail since graduation, and I'm just...stuck. I don't even know where to start looking for something different.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand. It's common to feel that way, especially after graduating. Let's start by exploring your skills and interests. Beyond teaching, what aspects of English Literature did you enjoy? What are you naturally good at, and what do you genuinely enjoy doing, even outside of work?

turns.utterance: Well, I enjoyed the writing and research aspects of my degree. I was good at analyzing texts and formulating arguments. turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's helpful! So, writing, research, analysis, and a possible interest in creative writing. turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a valid point. Many entry-level positions do seem to require experience. To address this, consider building a portfolio. You could start a blog showcasing your writing, volunteer to write content for a non-profit, or take on freelance projects through platforms like Upwork. Internships can also provide valuable experience, even if they are unpaid. Which path seems the most feasible and interesting to you?
